awd_titl_txt: Examining Undergraduate Attitudes Toward the Use of Mathematics in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Texas at Austin has received an NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Exploration Track award to develop and utilize an instrument to measure the extent to which undergraduate life science majors value mathematics for understanding and answering biological questions.  According to expectancy-value theory, the personal values assigned to a task, such as using mathematics to understand and make predictions about biological phenomena ("mathematics-biology tasks"), can influence a student's decision to enroll in future courses related to the task and their performance on the task. Thus, cultivating life science majors' value of mathematics-biology tasks is critical to their overall ability to apply quantitative skills and to the development of quantitative biologists.
 
To accomplish this, an existing, validated mathematics task-value instrument, the Mathematics Value Inventory (MVI), will be adapted and empirically validated to produce the Mathematics-Biology Value Instrument (MBVI).  The MBVI will measure four dimensions of student value of using mathematics in biology: enjoyment, usefulness, need for high achievement, and perceived cost.  With guidance from an Advisory Board consisting of experts in psychometrics, statistical analysis, and quantitative biology education, the PI team will use an iterative cycle of formative assessment and revision that will produce a valid and reliable measure for determining the extent to which life science majors value mathematics-biology tasks.  This instrument will be used to assess the landscape of life science majors' mathematics-biology task-values, including any differences between male and female, introductory and upper-level, and majority and minority students at institutions implementing different types of quantitative biology education reforms.

por.por_cntn:
Biology is becoming an increasingly quantitative science. Therefore, it is critical for undergraduate life science majors to develop quantitative skills. However, biology majors have traditionally been characterized as math-averse. Negative mathematics attitudes can actually impede student learning of quantitative skills; students with negative mathematics attitudes are less likely to fully engage with or persist on quantitative tasks. The overall goal of this project was to characterize the landscape of life science majors’ motivational attitudes toward the use of mathematics in the context of biology. Specifically, I focused on examining students’ interest in using mathematics to understand biology, their perceptions of how valuable mathematics is for their life science career, and their perceptions of the cost (e.g., extra effort or anxiety) of incorporating mathematics into their biology courses, collectively called math-biology task values. This project aimed to (1) create a survey to measure life science majors’ math-biology task values, (2) determine the landscape of students’ math-biology task values, (3) determine how students’ backgrounds influence their math-biology task values, and (4) determine the extent to which quantitative biology curricula in undergraduate introductory biology courses can influence students’ math-biology task values over the course of one semester.

 

In order to understand how life science majors value mathematics in the context of biology, it was first necessary to develop a survey to measure this. I followed rigorous guidelines for survey development, including iterative revisions of questions based on expert and student feedback. The resulting survey was deployed at nineteen different institutions across the US to characterize students’ math-biology task values, and 1,190 life science majors responded. A series of analyses revealed the following:

  • On average, life science majors see value in mathematics for their future life science career, are neutral with regards to their interest in using mathematics to understand biology, but perceive some cost to incorporating mathematics into biology courses (for example, anxiety at the idea of using mathematics in biology courses). These data suggest that many students may be receptive to mathematics in their biology courses, but that curricula should be designed to boost students’ interest in using mathematics to understand biology and decrease anxiety and worry they have about using mathematics in their biology courses.
  • The demographics of students influenced their math-biology task values. Women and students who are the first in their family to attend college had less positive math-biology task values than men or students not first in their family to attend college, respectively.
  • The academic background of students also influenced their math-biology task values. Students who took calculus as their highest high school math course had more positive math-biology task values than students who took pre-calculus, algebra, or statistics as their highest high school math course. Additionally, fourth-year students reported significantly lower perceptions of the cost of incorporating mathematics into their biology courses than first-year students.
  • Students reported that their likelihood of taking additional quantitative biology courses in college was influenced by their math-biology task values. Students with a greater interest in using mathematics to understand biology and lower perceptions of the cost of incorporating mathematics into biology courses reported that they were more likely to take an upper-level mathematical modeling course. Students with a greater interest in using mathematics to understand biology and greater perceptions of the value of mathematics for their life science career reported that they were more likely to take an upper-level biostatistics course. These results demonstrate that students’ math-biology values can influence their decision to pursue quantitative biology training as an undergraduate.

 

Finally, the survey was distributed to students in introductory biology courses at three institutions that used different curricula to integrate quantitative skills into the introductory biology courses. Students were asked to report on their math-biology values at the beginning of the course, and again at the end of the course. Analyses of these data revealed positive changes in students’ math-biology task values at one of the three institutions. This suggests that it is possible to positively influence life science majors’ attitudes towards mathematics in one semester, but that not all curricula or ways in which a curriculum is implemented will result in these gains. These results raise questions about the components of a curriculum or its implementation that are necessary for positive changes in math-biology task values and the time it takes to see substantial changes in math-biology task values (e.g., over one semester vs. over four years).

 

This study has provided insight into the attitudes of life science majors regarding mathematics in their biology courses. Understanding these attitudes is important for addressing challenges related to student learning of quantitative skills. Moreover, this study has produced a new tool that can be used for further educational research on students’ motivational attitudes related to quantitative biology, or for aiding in the assessment of the efficacy of a quantitative biology curriculum.
